publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Quid non Mortalia pectora Cogis Auri Særa fames
Fair ones to insyou who Hearts Command
And Gently Sway with Fan in hand
Your Favorite Punch a Supliant Falls
And Humbly for Assistance Calls
He humbly Calls and begs you'l stop
The Gothic overk Rage of 1······ Hopkins Esqr Master of the Revels & Secatary to his Grace ye Duke of Grafton wn he was Lord Lieut of Ierland Vander Hop
Who Invades without Pretence or Right
Or any Law but that of Might
Our Pigmy──land, and treats Our Kings
Like Paltry Idle Wooden Things
Has beat Our Dancer of Doors
And Call'd Our Chastest Virgins Whores
Nor has he left Our Queen a Rag on
Has forc'd Away Our George and Dragon
Has broke Our Wyers, nor was he Civil
To Doctor Faustus or the Divel
E'ne me he hurry'd with fell Rage
Most hoarsly Squawling of the Stage
And faith Our fright was very great
To See a Minister of State
Arm'd with Power and Fury come
To force us from Our little home
Who fear'd, as I am Sure we had reason
An Accusation of high Treason
Till starting up! Crys Benamere
Treason──my Friends we need not Fear
For against the Brass, we Us'd no Power
Nor strove to Save the Chancellor
Nor did we shew the least affection
To Rochfort on Westmeath Election
Nor did we Sing──Mac-Hugh he means.──
Thou Villain──I'le dash out thy brains
It is no affair of State that brings
Me here──nor business of the Kings
I come to Seize you all as Debtors
And bind you fast in Iron Fetters
From Sight of ev'ry friend in Town
Till fifty pound to me's paid Down.
Fifty──Quoth I──a Divilish Sum
But stay till the new half-pence come
Then shall we all be Rich as Iews
From Castle down to lowest Stews
That Sum to you shall then be told
Tho now we cannot Furnish Gold.──
Quoth he──thou lovest Punch to prate
And Could'st for Ever hold Debate
But thinkst thou that I've Nought to do
But Trifle time away with You
Or dost thou think that I can come
To Carry nought but farthings home
Thou I ne're do things by halves
Farthings are made for Irish slaves
No Brass for me──I must be Gold
Or fifty pounds in Silver told.
That can by any means Obtain,
Freedom for thee, And for this TrainVotre tres humble Serviteur.
I am not in jest Said I──I'm Sure
But from the Bottom of my Belly
In Sober Sadness, It is I tell you
I think it is good Reasoning
For us fictitious men to bring
Brass Counters made by William Wood
Which may as well be Understood
Intrinsick, As We flesh & Blood
Then Since We are but Mimick Men
Pray let us let us pay in Mimick Coyn
Besides its said that You and I
Are of insthe self same Family,
And faith, I'me apt to think so too.
For who is liker me then You
For the Same Grave and Aukward Grace
Shews forth it Self in Either face
And each of us with labour Struts
Behind a Tun at least of Guts
We tally well in these respects
And best of all in Intellects
For when you made distinction learn'd
Twixt the words Sorry and Concern'd
And when upon a Grave affair
Amazed you Gaped behind the Chair
They Cry'd──How like to Punchanello
Is that Same Fat, Clod Pated Fellow
Then Prithy Cozen let us Buss
And Cease to treat thy kindred thus.
Quoth he Thou Vile mishapen beast
Thou knave am I become thy Iest
Now not a Puppet of you all
Shall stir a step without this wall
Nor Merry Andrew beat his Drum
Untill you pay the aforesaid Sum
Then Marching off with Soluem Pace
To write dispatches for his Grace
The Revel Masr- left the room
And us Condem'd to fatal Doom
Now fair Ones if I 'ere found Grace
Or if my Ioakes did Ever please
Use all your Interst with the Seck
They Say he is at the Ladies Beck
And thô he inserted with caret thirsts as much for Gold
As Ever Midas did of Old
Your Charmes I am Sure can never fail
Your Eyes must Influence, Must prevail
At your Command he'l Set us free
Let us to you Owe Liberty
Get us a Lycence now to play
And as in Duty bound We'l PrayY08B020B
